quote: I use AI to find recipes with what I have in my fridge, to help me write emails when I need a particular tone or phrasing that I can't find.
use Tilt prompts: "Find me a restaurant near the beach, open on a Saturday night, where I can enjoy both seafood and meat for my companion."

For recipes, I tell Liya what I have in my fridge and in my pantry. I tell it that I'm looking for a healthy recipe ready in under 30 minutes. If the recipe I get doesn't suit me, I ask it to try other recipes.

I couldn't do it because the file was too big, there were two hundred and fifty names, and it told me the file was too large and that with the free version I couldn't do what I wanted. So I had to do it manually.

The size limitation was no longer the main issue. So the problem was it created lists with a lot of duplicates. For example, we had Mathilde twice in the same team, or Mathilde was in three different teams, so it was impossible.
I still had to go back and redo it 100% myself, because in fact it was too long to make sure each team was correct. It was faster to do it myself and start over.

For me, a perfect personal system would be one that would help me in my personal life to manage my mental load, notably by allowing me to save time, for example to do the shopping or to schedule appointments with the doctor or the vet.

it's someone who would take initiative, more than an assistant who would wait for me to tell it to do things. How would it be better than current tools? I think it's precisely the proactivity versus passivity part.

I notice there's no butter left in the fridge, and I therefore add butter to my shopping list. The productivity gain would be that, via my Drive app, it would directly add the butter to my basket, knowing it's the butter I usually buy, since it knows.

analyzing the fact that I go to the hairdresser every six weeks and reminding me to make an appointment a few weeks before, automatically recording the appointments in my calendar and having reminders the day before, for example one hour before.

it's scanning my life habits to simplify my life and propose initiatives that align with my usual lifestyle, whether for shopping, recipes, or appointments at the beautician, the hairdresser, the doctor, etc., when these are habitual things that keep recurring.

In case of a change in routine, for example, if Sylvia sees that the slot is blocked, the hairdresser doesn't come every 6 weeks but every 8 weeks, to ask me whether I want to keep this new habit and therefore schedule all my future appointments on an 8-week basis, or if it's exceptional and it should keep its usual routine outside of this event.

the goal would be for the AI to indeed be connected, for example, to my calendar, to my shopping list, to my Drive app, to my Planity app for the hairdresser or for regular appointments, like the beautician, etc.

we regularly eat the same things, so that it would be connected to my Notes app where I have all my recipes, so that I could get relevant recipes according to my tastes, which it knows thanks to all the recipes I've already saved.

I think AI is less spontaneous than a human. It sticks to a given script, whereas a human will bounce off my expressions, emotions and the unsaid parts of my sentence to ask even more targeted questions. AI, for its part, will stay a bit more within its script.
I have the impression that the questions [are] maybe a bit redundant compared to the first questions; we're unable to ask it [to] clarify certain things

the AI could also help me in managing all my emails and in scheduling appointments with the bank if the bank [sends] me an email to offer me an appointment [that] [still] [checks] my calendar to see if I'm available [and] if that's the case to be able to offer to send [emails] on my behalf to confirm the appointment with the bank, etc.
it prevents spontaneity on [our] side and stops us from probing certain answers that could be interesting for the human
